```
# Load required libraries
library(ggplot2)
library(pheatmap)

# Read data
exp_data <- read.table("leukemiaExp.txt", header = TRUE, row.names = 1, sep = "\t", check.names = FALSE)

# Compute standard deviation for each gene (row)
gene_sd <- apply(exp_data, 1, sd)

# Order genes based on their standard deviation in decreasing order
ordered_genes <- order(gene_sd, decreasing = TRUE)

# Keep only the top 1000 most variable genes
filtered_exp_data <- exp_data[ordered_genes[1:1000], ]

# Plot heatmap
pheatmap(filtered_exp_data,
         scale = "row",
         clustering_distance_rows = "correlation",
         clustering_distance_cols = "correlation",
         clustering_method = "complete")

# Perform PCA
pca_res <- prcomp(t(filtered_exp_data), scale. = TRUE)

# Create dataframe for ggplot
df <- data.frame(PC1 = pca_res$x[,1], 
                 PC2 = pca_res$x[,2])

# Plot PCA
ggplot(df, aes(x=PC1, y=PC2)) +
  geom_point(size=2) +
  labs(x="PC1", y="PC2") +
  theme_minimal()
```
This code will first calculate the standard deviation of gene expressions across all samples for each gene. Then, it will select the top 1000 genes with the highest standard deviation (most variable genes). Then, a heatmap of these, variable genes is plotted. Finally, Principal Component Analysis (PCA) is conducted on the selected gene expressions and result is visualized in a scatter plot. Note that dimensions are scaled for PCA.
